Parsing [sent. 5334 len. 45]: Wingfold tried hard to forget Mrs. Ramshorn 's , and one or two besides , and by the time he came to the sermon , thought of nothing but human hearts , their agonies , and him who came to call them to him .
Parsing [sent. 5335 len. 15]: `` I came not to call the righteous , but sinners to repentance . ''
Parsing [sent. 5336 len. 21]: `` Was it then of the sinners first our Lord thought ere he came from the bosom of the Father ?
Parsing [sent. 5337 len. 38]: Did the perfect will embrace in the all-atoning tenderness of the divine heart , the degraded , disfigured , defiled , distorted thing , whose angel is too blind ever to see the face of its Father ?
Parsing [sent. 5338 len. 34]: Through all the hideous filth of the charnel-house , which the passions had heaped upon her , did the Word recognise the bound , wing-lamed , feather-draggled Psyche , panting in horriblest torture ?
Parsing [sent. 5339 len. 38]: Did he have a desire to the work of his hands , the child of his father 's heart , and therefore , strong in compassion , speed to the painful rescue of hearts like his own ?
Parsing [sent. 5340 len. 18]: That purity arid defilement should thus meet across all the great dividing gulf of law and morals !
Parsing [sent. 5341 len. 7]: The friend of publicans and sinners !
Parsing [sent. 5342 len. 9]: Think : he was absolutely friendly with them !
Parsing [sent. 5343 len. 6]: was not shocked at them !
Parsing [sent. 5344 len. 7]: held up no hands of dismay !
Parsing [sent. 5345 len. 8]: Only they must do so no more .
Parsing [sent. 5346 len. 36]: `` If he were to come again , visibly , now , which do you think would come crowding around him in greater numbers -- the respectable church-goers , or the people from the slums ?
Parsing [sent. 5347 len. 5]: I do not know .
Parsing [sent. 5348 len. 5]: I dare not judge .
Parsing [sent. 5349 len. 43]: But the fact that the church draws so few of those that are despised , of those whom Jesus drew and to whom most expressly he came , gives ground for question as to how far the church is like her Lord .
Parsing [sent. 5350 len. 42]: Certainly many a one would find the way to the feet of the master , from whom the respectable church-goer , the pharisee of our time , and the priest who stands on his profession , would draw back with disgust .
Parsing [sent. 5351 len. 83]: And doubtless it would be in the religious world that a man like Jesus , who , without a professional education , a craftsman by birth and early training , uttered scarce a phrase endorsed by clerical use , or a word of the religious cant of the day , but taught in simplest natural forms the eternal facts of faith and hope and love , would meet with the chief and perhaps the only BITTER opponents of his doctrine and life .
Parsing [sent. 5352 len. 10]: `` But did our Lord not call the righteous ?
Parsing [sent. 5353 len. 51]: Did he not call honest men about him -- James and John and Simon -- sturdy fisher-folk , who faced the night and the storm , worked hard , fared roughly , lived honestly , and led good cleanly lives with father and mother , or with wife and children ?
Parsing [sent. 5354 len. 21]: I do not know that he said anything special to convince them that they were sinners before he called them .
Parsing [sent. 5355 len. 46]: But it is to be remarked that one of the first effects of his company upon Simon Peter was , that the fisherman grew ashamed of himself , and while ashamed was yet possessed with an impulse of openness and honesty no less than passionate .
Parsing [sent. 5356 len. 17]: The pure man should not be deceived as to what sort of company he was in !
Parsing [sent. 5357 len. 16]: ` Depart from me , for I am a sinful man , O Lord ! '
Parsing [sent. 5358 len. 24]: I would I could clearly behold with my mind 's eye what he then saw in Jesus that drew from him that cry !
Parsing [sent. 5359 len. 24]: fle knew him for the Messiah : what was the working of the carpenter upon the fisherman that satisfied him of the fact ?
Parsing [sent. 5360 len. 18]: Would the miracle have done it but for the previous talk from the boat to the people ?
Parsing [sent. 5361 len. 4]: I think not .
Parsing [sent. 5362 len. 37]: Anyhow St. Peter judged himself among the sinners , and we may be sure that if these fishers had been self-satisfied men , they would not have left all and gone after him who called them .
Parsing [sent. 5363 len. 16]: Still it would hardly seern that it was specially as sinners that he did so .
Parsing [sent. 5364 len. 75]: Again , did not men such as the Lord himself regarded as righteous come to him -- Nicodemus , Nathaniel , the young man who came running and kneeled to him , the scribe who was not far from the kingdom , the centurion , in whom he found more faith than in any Jew , he who had built a synagogue in Capernaum , and sculptured on its lintel the pot of manna ?
Parsing [sent. 5365 len. 15]: These came to him , and we know he was ready to receive them .
Parsing [sent. 5366 len. 56]: But he knew such would always come drawn of the Father ; they did not want much calling ; they were not so much in his thoughts therefore ; he was not troubled about them ; they were as the ninety and nine , the elder son at home , the money in the purse .
Parsing [sent. 5367 len. 22]: Doubtless they had much to learn , were not yet in the kingdom , but they were crowding about its door .
Parsing [sent. 5368 len. 18]: If I set it forth aright , I know not , but thus it looks to me .
Parsing [sent. 5369 len. 27]: And one thing I can not forget -- it meets me in the face -- that some at least , -- who knows if not all ?
Parsing [sent. 5370 len. 13]: -- of the purest of men have counted themselves the greatest sinners !
Parsing [sent. 5371 len. 48]: Neither can I forget that other saying of our Lord , a stumbling-block to many -- our Lord was not so careful as perhaps some would have had him , lest men should stumble at the truth -- The first shall be last and the last first .
Parsing [sent. 5372 len. 68]: While our Lord spoke the words : The time cometh that whosoever killeth you will think that he doeth God service , even then was Saul of Tarsus at the feet of Gamaliel , preparing to do God that service ; but like one born out of due time , after all the rest he saw the Lord , and became the chief in labour and suffering .
Parsing [sent. 5373 len. 6]: Thus the last became first .
Parsing [sent. 5374 len. 61]: And I bethink me that the beloved disciple , who leaned on the bosom of the Lord , who was bolder to ask him than any -- with the boldness of love , he whom the meek and lowly called a Son of Thunder , was the last of all to rejoin the master in the mansions of his Father .
Parsing [sent. 5375 len. 11]: Last or first -- if only we are with him !
Parsing [sent. 5376 len. 18]: One thing is clear that in the order of the Lord 's business , first came sinners .
Parsing [sent. 5377 len. 27]: `` Who that reflects can fail to see this at least , that a crime brings a man face to face with the reality of things ?
Parsing [sent. 5378 len. 69]: He who knows himself a sinner -- I do not mean as one of the race -- the most self-righteous man will allow that as a man he is a sinner -- he to whom , in the words of the communion service , the remembrance of his sins is grievous , and the burden of them intolerable , knows in himself that he is a lost man .
Parsing [sent. 5379 len. 45]: He can no more hold up his head among his kind ; he can not look a woman or a child in the face ; he can not be left alone with the chaos of his thoughts , and the monsters it momently breeds .
Parsing [sent. 5380 len. 16]: The joys of his childhood , the delights of existence , are gone from him .
Parsing [sent. 5381 len. 12]: There dwells within him an ever present judgment and fiery indignation .
Parsing [sent. 5382 len. 26]: Such a man will start at the sound of pardon and peace , even as the camel of the desert at the scent of water .
Parsing [sent. 5383 len. 101]: Therefore surely is such a man nearer to the gate of the kingdom than he against whom the world has never wagged a tongue , who never sinned against a social custom even , and has as easy a conscience as the day he was born ; but who knows so little of himself that , while he thinks he is good enough , he carries within him the capacity and possibility of every cardinal sin , waiting only the special and fitting temptation which , like the match to the charged mine , shall set all in a roar !
Parsing [sent. 5384 len. 79]: Of this danger he knows nothing , never dreams of praying against it , takes his seat in his pew Sunday after Sunday with his family , nor ever murmurs Lead us not into temptation with the least sense that temptation is a frightful thing , but repeats and responds and listens in perfect self-satisfaction , doubting never that a world made up of such as he must be a pleasant sight in the eyes of the Perfect .
Parsing [sent. 5385 len. 23]: There are men who will never see what they are capable or in danger of until they have committed some fearful wrong .
Parsing [sent. 5386 len. 42]: Nay there are some for whom even that is not enough ; they must be found out by their fellow-men , and scorned in the eyes of the world , before they can or will admit or comprehend their own disgrace .
Parsing [sent. 5387 len. 8]: And there are worse still than these .
Parsing [sent. 5388 len. 21]: `` But a man may be oppressed by his sins , and hardly know what it is that oppresses him .
Parsing [sent. 5389 len. 14]: There is more of sin in our burdens than we are ourselves aware .
Parsing [sent. 5390 len. 12]: It needs not that we should have committed any grievous fault .
Parsing [sent. 5391 len. 73]: Do we recognize in ourselves that which needs to be set right , that of which we ought to be ashamed , something which , were we lifted above all worldly anxieties , would yet keep us uneasy , dissatisfied , take the essential gladness out of the sunlight , make the fair face of the earth indifferent to us , a trustful glance a discomposing look , and death a darkness ?
Parsing [sent. 5392 len. 39]: -- I say to the man who feels thus , whatever he may have done or left undone , he is not so far from the kingdom of heaven but that he may enter thereinto if he will .
Parsing [sent. 5393 len. 50]: `` And if there be here any soul withered up with dismay , torn with horrible wonder that he should have done the deed which he yet hath done , to him I say -- Flee from the self that hath sinned and hide thee with Christ in God .
Parsing [sent. 5394 len. 95]: Or if the words sound to thee as the words of some unknown tongue , and I am to thee as one that beateth the air , I say instead -- Call aloud in thy agony , that , if there be a God , he may hear the voice of his child , and put forth his hand and lay hold upon him , and rend from him the garment that clings and poisons and burns , squeeze the black drop from his heart , and set him weeping like a summer rain .
Parsing [sent. 5395 len. 28]: O blessed , holy , lovely repentance to which the Son of Man , the very root and man of men , hath come to call us !
Parsing [sent. 5396 len. 9]: Good it is , and I know it .
Parsing [sent. 5397 len. 24]: Come and repent with me , O heart wounded by thine own injustice and wrong , and together we will seek the merciful .
Parsing [sent. 5398 len. 19]: Think not about thy sin so as to make it either less or greater in thine own eyes .
Parsing [sent. 5399 len. 17]: Bring it to Jesus , and let him show thee how vile a thing it is .
Parsing [sent. 5400 len. 58]: And leave it to him to judge thee -- sure that he will judge thee justly , extenuating nothing , for he hath to cleanse thee utterly , and yet forgetting no smallest excuse that may cover the amazement of thy guilt , or witness for thee that not with open eyes didst thou do the deed .
Parsing [sent. 5401 len. 18]: At the last he cried , Father forgive them , for they know not what they do .
Parsing [sent. 5402 len. 21]: For his enemies the truth should be spoken , his first words when they had nailed him to the cross .
Parsing [sent. 5403 len. 48]: But again I say , let it be Christ that excuseth thee ; he will do it to more purpose than thou , and will not wrong thy soul by excusing thee a hair too much , or thy heart by excusing thee a hair too little .
Parsing [sent. 5404 len. 12]: `` I dreamed once that I had committed a terrible crime .
Parsing [sent. 5405 len. 20]: Carried beyond myself by passion , I knew not at the moment HOW evil was the thing I did .
Parsing [sent. 5406 len. 7]: But I knew it was evil .
Parsing [sent. 5407 len. 22]: And suddenly I became aware , when it was too late , of the nature of that which I had done .
Parsing [sent. 5408 len. 19]: The horror that came with the knowledge was of the things that belong only to the secret soul .
Parsing [sent. 5409 len. 33]: I was the same man as before I did it , yet was I now a man of whom my former self could not have conceived the possibility as dwelling within it .
Parsing [sent. 5410 len. 32]: The former self seemed now by contrast lovely in purity , yet out of that seeming purity this fearful , foul _ I _ of the present had just been born !
Parsing [sent. 5411 len. 17]: The face of my fellow-man was an avenging law , the face of a just enemy .
Parsing [sent. 5412 len. 11]: Where , how , should the frightful face be hidden ?
Parsing [sent. 5413 len. 20]: The conscious earth must take it into its wounded bosom , and that before the all-seeing daylight should come .
Parsing [sent. 5414 len. 22]: But it would come , and I should stand therein pointed at by every ray that shot through the sunny atmosphere !
Parsing [sent. 5415 len. 21]: `` The agony was of its own kind , and I have no word to tell what it was like .
Parsing [sent. 5416 len. 17]: An evil odour and a sickening pain combined , might be a symbol of the torture .
Parsing [sent. 5417 len. 51]: As is in the nature of dreams , possibly I lay but a little second on the rack , yet an age seemed shot through and through with the burning meshes of that crime , while , cowering and terror-stricken , I tossed about the loathsome fact in my mind .
Parsing [sent. 5418 len. 22]: I had DONE it , and from the done there was no escape : it was for evermore a thing done .
Parsing [sent. 5419 len. 9]: -- Came a sudden change : I awoke .
Parsing [sent. 5420 len. 26]: The sun stained with glory the curtains of my room , and the light of light darted keen as an arrow into my very soul .
Parsing [sent. 5421 len. 4]: Glory to God !
Parsing [sent. 5422 len. 4]: I was innocent !
Parsing [sent. 5423 len. 8]: The stone was rolled from my sepulchre .
Parsing [sent. 5424 len. 18]: With the darkness whence it had sprung , the cloud of my crime went heaving lurid away .
Parsing [sent. 5425 len. 13]: I was a creature of the light and not of the dark .
Parsing [sent. 5426 len. 23]: For me the sun shone and the wind blew ; for me the sea roared and the flowers sent up their odours .
Parsing [sent. 5427 len. 9]: For me the earth had nothing to hide .
Parsing [sent. 5428 len. 42]: My guilt was wiped away ; there was no red worm gnawing at my heart ; I could look my neighbour in the face , and the child of my friend might lay his hand in mine and not be defiled !
Parsing [sent. 5429 len. 15]: All day long the joy of that deliverance kept surging on in my soul .
Parsing [sent. 5430 len. 73]: `` But something yet more precious , more lovely than such an awaking , will repentance be to the sinner ; for after all it was but a dream of the night from which that set me free , and the spectre-deed that vanished had never had a place in the world of fact ; while the horror from which repentance delivers , is no dream , but a stubborn abiding reality .
Parsing [sent. 5431 len. 63]: Again , the vanishing vision leaves the man what he was before , still capable it may be of committing the crime from which he is not altogether clean to whom in his sleep it was possible : repentance makes of the man a new creature , one who has awaked from the sleep of sin to sleep that sleep no more .
Parsing [sent. 5432 len. 17]: The change in the one case is not for greatness comparable with that in the other .
Parsing [sent. 5433 len. 119]: The sun that awakes from the one sleep , is but the outward sun of our earthly life -- a glorious indeed and lovely thing , which yet even now is gathering a crust of darkness , blotting itself out and vanishing : the sun that awakes a man from the sleep of death is the living Sun that casts from his thought out into being that other sun , with the space wherein it holds planetary court -- the Father of lights , before whose shining in the inner world of truth eternal , even the deeds of vice become as spectral dreams , and , with the night of godlessness that engendered them , flee away .
Parsing [sent. 5434 len. 23]: `` But a man may answer and say to me -- ` Thou art but borne on the wings of thine imagination .
Parsing [sent. 5435 len. 30]: The fact of the crime remains , let a man tear out his heart in repentance , and no awaking can restore an innocence which is indeed lost . '
Parsing [sent. 5436 len. 35]: I answer : The words thou speakest are in themselves true , yet thy ignorance makes them false , Thou knowest not the power of God , nor what resurrection from the dead means .
Parsing [sent. 5437 len. 53]: What if , while it restored not thy former innocence , it brought thee a purity by the side of whose white splendour and inward preciousness , the innocence thou hadst lost was but a bauble , being but a thing that turned to dross in the first furnace of its temptation ?
Parsing [sent. 5438 len. 44]: Innocence is indeed priceless -- that innocence which God counteth innocence , but thine was a flimsy show , a bit of polished and cherished glass -- instead of which , if thou repentest , thou shalt in thy jewel-box find a diamond .
Parsing [sent. 5439 len. 44]: Is thy purity , O fair Psyche of the social world , upon whose wings no spattering shower has yet cast an earthy stain , and who knowest not yet whether there be any such thing as repentance or need of the same !
Parsing [sent. 5440 len. 49]: -- is thy purity to compare with the purity of that heavenly Psyche , twice born , who even now in the twilight-slumbers of heaven , dreams that she washes with her tears the feet of her Lord , and wipes them with the hairs of her head ?
Parsing [sent. 5441 len. 14]: O bountiful God , who wilt give us back even our innocence tenfold !
Parsing [sent. 5442 len. 28]: He can give an awaking that leaves the past of the soul ten times farther behind than ever waking from sleep left the dreams of the night .
Parsing [sent. 5443 len. 77]: `` If the potency of that awaking lay in the inrush of a new billow of life , fresh from its original source , carrying with it an enlargement of the whole nature and its every part , a glorification of every faculty , every sense even , so that the man , forgetting nothing of his past or its shame , should yet cry out in the joy of his second birth : ` Lo !
Parsing [sent. 5444 len. 29]: I am a new man ; I am no more he who did that awful and evil thing , for I am no more capable of doing it !
Parsing [sent. 5445 len. 10]: God be praised , for all is well ! '
Parsing [sent. 5446 len. 55]: -- would not such an awaking send the past afar into the dim distance of the first creation , and wrap the ill deed in the clean linen cloth of forgiveness , even as the dull creature of the sea rolls up the grain of intruding sand in the lovely garment of a pearl ?
Parsing [sent. 5447 len. 23]: Such an awaking means God himself in the soul , not disdaining closest vital company with the creature he foresaw and created .
Parsing [sent. 5448 len. 15]: And the man knows in full content that he is healed of his plague .
Parsing [sent. 5449 len. 49]: Nor would he willingly lose the scars which record its outbreak , for they tell him what he is without God , and set him ever looking to see that the door into the heavenly garden stands wide for God to enter the house when it pleases him .
Parsing [sent. 5450 len. 32]: And who can tell whether , in the train of such an awaking , may not follow a thousand opportunities and means of making amends to those whom he has injured ?
Parsing [sent. 5451 len. 43]: `` Nor must I fail to remind the man who has committed no grievous crime , that except he has repented of his evil self , and abjured all wrong , he is not safe from any , even the worst offence .
Parsing [sent. 5452 len. 49]: There was a time when I could not understand that he who loved not his brother was a murderer : now I see it to be no figure of speech , but , in the realities of man 's moral and spiritual nature , an absolute simple fact .
Parsing [sent. 5453 len. 17]: The murderer and the unloving sit on the same bench before the judge of eternal truth .
Parsing [sent. 5454 len. 42]: The man who loves not his brother , I do not say is at this moment capable of killing him , but if the natural working of his unlove be not checked , he will assuredly become capable of killing him .
Parsing [sent. 5455 len. 30]: Until we love our brother , yes , until we love our enemy , who is yet our brother , we contain within ourselves the undeveloped germ of murder .
Parsing [sent. 5456 len. 14]: And so with every sin in the tables or out of the tables .
Parsing [sent. 5457 len. 30]: There is not one in this congregation who has a right to cast a look of reproach at the worst felon who ever sat in the prisoners ' dock .
Parsing [sent. 5458 len. 9]: I speak no hyperbole , but simple truth .
Parsing [sent. 5459 len. 42]: We are very ready to draw in our minds a distinction between respectable sins -- human imperfections we call them , perhaps -- and disreputable vices , such as theft and murder ; but there is no such distinction in fact .
Parsing [sent. 5460 len. 22]: Many a thief is a better man than many a clergyman , and miles nearer to the gate of the kingdom .
Parsing [sent. 5461 len. 26]: The heavenly order goes upon other principles than ours , and there are first that shall be last , and last that shall be first .
Parsing [sent. 5462 len. 12]: Only , at the root of all human bliss lies repentance .
Parsing [sent. 5463 len. 47]: `` Come then at the call of the Water , the Healer , the Giver of repentance and light , the Friend of publicans and sinners , all ye on whom lies the weight of a sin , or the gathered heap of a thousand crimes .
Parsing [sent. 5464 len. 17]: He came to call such as you , that he might make you clear and clean .
Parsing [sent. 5465 len. 21]: He can not bear that you should live on in such misery , such badness , such blackness of darkness .
Parsing [sent. 5466 len. 14]: He would give you again your life , the bliss of your being .
Parsing [sent. 5467 len. 24]: He will not speak to you one word of reproach , except indeed you should aim at justifying yourselves by accusing your neighbour .
Parsing [sent. 5468 len. 29]: He will leave it to those who cherish the same sins in their hearts to cast stones at you : he who has no sin casts no stone .
Parsing [sent. 5469 len. 29]: Heartily he loves you , heartily he hates the evil in you -- so heartily that he will even cast you into the fire to burn you clean .
Parsing [sent. 5470 len. 10]: By making you clean he will give you rest .
Parsing [sent. 5471 len. 28]: If he upbraid , it will not be for past sin , but for the present little faith , holding out to him an acorn-cup to fill .
Parsing [sent. 5472 len. 69]: The rest of you keep aloof , if you will , until you shall have done some deed that compels you to cry out for deliverance ; but you that know yourselves sinners , come to him that he may work in you his perfect work , for he came not to call the righteous , but sinners , us , you and me , to repentance . ''
Parsing [sent. 5473 len. 6]: END OF THE SECOND VOLUME .
Parsing [sent. 5474 len. 3]: VOL III .
Parsing [sent. 5475 len. 3]: CHAPTER I .
Parsing [sent. 5476 len. 4]: AFTER THE SERMON .
Parsing [sent. 5477 len. 32]: As the sermon drew to a close , and the mist of his emotion began to disperse , individual faces of his audience again dawned out on the preacher 's ken .
Parsing [sent. 5478 len. 7]: Mr. Drew 's head was down .
Parsing [sent. 5479 len. 92]: As I have always said , certain things he had been taught in his youth , and had practised in his manhood , certain mean ways counted honest enough in the trade , had become to him , regarded from the ideal point of the divine in merchandize -- such a merchandize , namely , as the share the son of man might have taken in buying and selling , had his reputed father been a shop-keeper instead of a carpenter -- absolutely hateful , and the memory of them intolerable .
Parsing [sent. 5480 len. 51]: Nor did it relieve him much to remind himself of the fact , that he knew not to the full the nature of the advantages he took , for he knew that he had known them such as shrunk from the light , not coming thereto to be made manifest .
Parsing [sent. 5481 len. 66]: He was now doing his best to banish them from his business , and yet they were a painful presence to his spirit -- so grievous to be borne , that the prospect held out by the preacher of an absolute and final deliverance from them by the indwelling presence of the God of all living men and true merchants , was a blessedness unspeakable .
Parsing [sent. 5482 len. 23]: Small was the suspicion in the Abbey Church of Olaston that morning , that the well-known successful man of business was weeping .
Parsing [sent. 5483 len. 32]: Who could once have imagined another reason for the laying of that round , good-humoured , contented face down on the book-board , than pure drowsiness from lack of work-day interest !
Parsing [sent. 5484 len. 12]: Yet there was a human soul crying out after its birthright .
Parsing [sent. 5485 len. 9]: Oh , to be clean as a mountain-river !
Parsing [sent. 5486 len. 14]: clean as the air above the clouds , or on the middle seas !
Parsing [sent. 5487 len. 13]: as the throbbing aether that fills the gulf betwixt star and star !
Parsing [sent. 5488 len. 68]: -- nay , as the thought of the Son of Man himself , who , to make all things new and clean , stood up against the old battery of sin-sprung suffering , withstanding and enduring and stilling the recoil of the awful force wherewith his Father had launched the worlds , and given birth to human souls with wills that might become free as his own !
Parsing [sent. 5489 len. 92]: While Wingfold had been speaking in general terms , with the race in his mind 's , and the congregation in his body 's eye , he had yet thought more of one soul , with its one crime and its intolerable burden , than all the rest : Leopold was ever present to him , and while he strove to avoid absorption in a personal interest however justifiable , it was of necessity that the thought of the most burdened sinner he knew should colour the whole of his utterance .
Parsing [sent. 5490 len. 54]: At times indeed he felt as if he were speaking to him immediately -- and to him only ; at others , although then he saw her no more than him , that he was comforting the sister individually , in holding out to her brother the mighty hope of a restored purity .
Parsing [sent. 5491 len. 30]: And when once more his mind could receive the messages brought home by his eyes , he saw upon Helen 's face the red sunset of a rapt listening .
Parsing [sent. 5492 len. 46]: True it was already fading away , but the eyes had wept , the glow yet hung about cheek and forehead , and the firm mouth had forgotten itself into a tremulous form , which the stillness of absorption had there for the moment fixed .
Parsing [sent. 5493 len. 55]: But even already , although he could not yet read it upon her countenance , a snake had begun to lift its head from the chaotic swamp which runs a creek at least into every soul , the rudimentary desolation , a remnant of the time when the world was without form and void .
Parsing [sent. 5494 len. 20]: And the snake said : `` Why , then , did he not speak like that to my Leopold ?
Parsing [sent. 5495 len. 20]: Why did he not comfort him with such a good hope , well-becoming a priest of the gentle Jesus ?
Parsing [sent. 5496 len. 55]: Or , if he fancied he must speak of confession , why did he not speak of it in plain honest terms , instead of suggesting the idea of it so that the poor boy imagined it came from his own spirit , and must therefore be obeyed as the will of God ? ''
Parsing [sent. 5497 len. 37]: So said the snake , and by the time Helen had walked home with her aunt , the glow had sunk from her soul , and a gray wintry mist had settled down upon her spirit .
Parsing [sent. 5498 len. 111]: And she said to herself that if this last hope in George should fail her , she would not allow the matter to trouble her any farther ; she was a free woman , and as Leopold had chosen other counsellors , had thus declared her unworthy of confidence , and , after all that she had suffered and done for love of him , had turned away from her , she would put money in her purse , set out for France or Italy , and leave him to the fate , whatever it might be , which his new advisers and his own obstinacy might bring upon him .
Parsing [sent. 5499 len. 12]: Was the innocent bound to share the shame of the guilty ?
Parsing [sent. 5500 len. 6]: Had she not done enough ?
Parsing [sent. 5501 len. 16]: Would even her father require more of her than she had already done and endured ?
Parsing [sent. 5502 len. 112]: When , therefore , she went into Leopold 's room , and his eyes sought her from the couch , she took no notice that he had got up and dressed while she was at church ; and he knew that a cloud had come between them , and that after all she had borne and done for him , he and his sister were now farther apart , for the time at least , than when oceans lay betwixt their birth and their meeting ; and he found himself looking back with vague longing even to the terrible old house of Glaston , and the sharing of their agony therein .
Parsing [sent. 5503 len. 25]: His eyes followed her as she walked across to the dressing-room , and the tears rose and filled them , but he said nothing .
Parsing [sent. 5504 len. 113]: And the sister who , all the time of the sermon , had been filled with wave upon wave of wishing -- that Poldie could hear this , could hear that , could have such a thought to comfort him , such a lovely word to drive the horror from his soul , now cast on him a chilly glance , and said never a word of the things to which she had listened with such heavings of the spirit-ocean ; for she felt , with an instinct more righteous than her will , that they would but strengthen him in his determination to do whatever the teacher of them might approve .

Parsing [sent. 6127 len. 44]: Verily it seems for many years ; but , knowing well the truth concerning the relations of time in him that dreameth and waketh from his dream , I place no confidence in the testimony of the impressions left upon my seeming memory .
Parsing [sent. 6128 len. 18]: I can however trust it sufficiently as to the character of the illusions that then possessed me .
Parsing [sent. 6129 len. 14]: I imagined myself an Englishman called Polwarth , of an ancient Cornish family .
Parsing [sent. 6130 len. 34]: Indeed , I had in my imagination , as Polwarth , gone through the history , every day of it , with its sunrise and sunset , of more than half a lifetime .
Parsing [sent. 6131 len. 83]: I had a brother who was deformed and a dwarf , and a daughter who was like him ; and the only thing , throughout the madness , that approached a consciousness of my real being and history , was the impression that these things had come upon me because of a certain grievous wrong I had at one time committed , which wrong , however , I had quite forgotten -- and could ill have imagined in its native hideousness . ''
Parsing [sent. 6132 len. 71]: ` But one morning , just as I woke , after a restless night filled with dreams , I was aware of a half-embodied shadow in my mind -- whether thought or memory or imagination , I could not tell : and the strange thing was , that it darkly radiated from it the conviction that I must hold and identify it , or be for ever lost to myself .
Parsing [sent. 6133 len. 53]: Therefore , with all the might of my will to retain the shadow , and all the energy of my recollection to recall that of which it was the vague shadow , I concentrated the whole power of my spiritual man upon the phantom thought , to fix and retain it . ''
Parsing [sent. 6134 len. 13]: ` Everyone knows what it is to hunt such a formless fact .
Parsing [sent. 6135 len. 24]: Evanescent as a rainbow , its whole appearance , from the first , is that of a thing in the act of vanishing .
Parsing [sent. 6136 len. 25]: It is a thing that was known , but , from the moment consciousness turned its lantern upon it , began to become invisible .
Parsing [sent. 6137 len. 77]: For a time , during the close pursuit that follows , it seems only to be turning corner after corner to evade the mind 's eye , but behind every corner it leaves a portion of itself ; until at length , although when finally can not be told , it is gone so utterly that the mind remains aghast in the perplexity of the doubt whether ever there was a thought there at all . ''
Parsing [sent. 6138 len. 37]: ` Throughout my delusion of an English existence , I had been tormented in my wakings with such thought-phantoms , and ever had I followed them , as an idle man may follow a flitting marsh-fire .
Parsing [sent. 6139 len. 74]: Indeed , I had grown so much interested in the phenomenon and its possible indications that I had invented various theories to account for them , some of which seemed to myself original and ingenious , while the common idea that they are vague reminiscences of a former state of being , I had again and again examined , and as often entirely rejected , as in no way tenable or verisimilar . ''
Parsing [sent. 6140 len. 31]: ` But upon the morning to which I have referred , I succeeded , for the first time , in fixing , capturing , identifying the haunting , fluttering thing .
Parsing [sent. 6141 len. 10]: That moment the bonds of my madness were broken .
Parsing [sent. 6142 len. 6]: My past returned upon me .
Parsing [sent. 6143 len. 27]: I had but to think in any direction , and every occurrence , with time and place and all its circumstance , rose again before me .
Parsing [sent. 6144 len. 74]: The awful fact of my own being once more stood bare -- awful always -- tenfold more awful after such a period of blissful oblivion thereof : I was , I had been , I am now , as I write , the man so mysterious in crime , so unlike all other men in his punishment , known by various names in various lands -- here in England as the Wandering Jew .
Parsing [sent. 6145 len. 7]: Ahasuerus was himself again , alas !
Parsing [sent. 6146 len. 6]: -- himself and no other .
Parsing [sent. 6147 len. 13]: Wife , daughter , brother vanished , and returned only in dreams .
Parsing [sent. 6148 len. 16]: I was and remain the wanderer , the undying , the repentant , the unforgiven .
Parsing [sent. 6149 len. 3]: O heart !
Parsing [sent. 6150 len. 4]: O weary feet !
Parsing [sent. 6151 len. 21]: O eyes that have seen and never more shall see , until they see once and are blinded for ever !
Parsing [sent. 6152 len. 45]: Back upon my soul rushes the memory of my deed , like a storm of hail mingled with fire , flashing through every old dry channel , that it throbs and writhes anew , scorched at once and torn with the poisonous burning . ''
Parsing [sent. 6153 len. 3]: CHAPTER XI .
Parsing [sent. 6154 len. 5]: THE WANDERING JEW . ''
Parsing [sent. 6155 len. 35]: ` It was a fair summer-morning in holy Jerusalem , and I sat and wrought at my trade , for I sewed a pair of sandals for the feet of the high priest Caiaphas .
Parsing [sent. 6156 len. 33]: And I wrought diligently , for it behoved me to cease an hour ere set of sun , for it was the day of preparation for the eating of the Passover . ''
Parsing [sent. 6157 len. 58]: ` Now all that night there had been a going to and fro in the city , for the chief priests and their followers had at length laid hands upon him that was called Jesus , whom some believed to be the Messiah , and others , with my fool-self amongst them , an arch-impostor and blasphemer .
Parsing [sent. 6158 len. 35]: For I was of the house of Caiaphas , and heartily did desire that the man my lord declared a deceiver of the people , should meet with the just reward of his doings .
Parsing [sent. 6159 len. 21]: Thus I sat and worked , and thought and rejoiced ; and the morning passed and the noon came . ''
Parsing [sent. 6160 len. 50]: ` It was a day of sultry summer , and the street burned beneath the sun , and I sat in the shadow and looked out upon the glare ; and ever I wrought at the sandals of my lord , with many fine stitches , in cunning workmanship .
Parsing [sent. 6161 len. 19]: All had been for some time very still , when suddenly I thought I heard a far-off tumult .
Parsing [sent. 6162 len. 31]: And soon came the idle children , who ever run first that they be not swallowed up of the crowd ; and they ran and looked behind as they ran .
Parsing [sent. 6163 len. 48]: And after them came the crowd , crying and shouting , and swaying hither and thither ; and in the midst of it arose the one arm of a cross , beneath the weight of which that same Jesus bent so low that I saw him not .
Parsing [sent. 6164 len. 60]: Truly , said I , he hath not seldom borne heavier burdens in the workshop of his father the Galilean , but now his sins and his idleness have found him , and taken from him his vigour ; for he that despiseth the law shall perish , while they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength .
Parsing [sent. 6165 len. 33]: For I was wroth with the man who taught the people to despise the great ones that administered the law , and give honour to the small ones who only kept it .
Parsing [sent. 6166 len. 57]: Besides , he had driven my father 's brother from the court of the Gentiles with a whip , which truly hurt him not outwardly , but stung him to the soul ; and yet that very temple which he pretended thus to honour , he had threatened to destroy and build again in three days !
Parsing [sent. 6167 len. 52]: Such were the thoughts of my heart ; and when I learned from the boys that it was in truth Jesus of Nazareth who passed on his way to Calvary to be crucified , my heart leaped within me at the thought that the law had at length overtaken the malefactor .
Parsing [sent. 6168 len. 23]: I laid down the sandal and my awl , and rose and went forth and stood in the front of my shop .
Parsing [sent. 6169 len. 22]: And Jesus drew nigh , and as he passed , lo , the end of the cross dragged upon the street .
Parsing [sent. 6170 len. 25]: And one in the crowd came behind , and lifted it up and pushed therewith , so that Jesus staggered and had nigh fallen .
Parsing [sent. 6171 len. 29]: Then would be fain have rested the arm of the cross on the stone by which I was wont to go up into my shop from the street .
Parsing [sent. 6172 len. 21]: But I cried out , and drove him thence , saying scornfully , `` Go on Jesus ; go on .
Parsing [sent. 6173 len. 10]: Truly thou restest not on stone of mine ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6174 len. 51]: Then turned he his eyes upon me , and said , `` I go indeed , but thou goest not ; '' and therewith he rose again under the weight of the cross , and staggered on , '' ` And I followed in the crowd to Calvary . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6175 len. 18]: Here the reader paused and said , `` I can give you but a few passages now .
Parsing [sent. 6176 len. 8]: You see it is a large manuscript .
Parsing [sent. 6177 len. 19]: I will therefore choose some of those that bear upon the subject of which we have been talking .
Parsing [sent. 6178 len. 19]: A detailed account of the crucifixion follows here , which I could not bring myself to read aloud .
Parsing [sent. 6179 len. 26]: The eclipse is in it , and the earthquake , and the white faces of the risen dead gleaming through the darkness about the cross .
Parsing [sent. 6180 len. 49]: It ends thus : '' ` And all the time , I stood not far from the foot of the cross , nor dared go nearer , for around it were his mother and they that were with her , and my heart was sore for her also .
Parsing [sent. 6181 len. 39]: And I would have withdrawn my foot from the place where I stood , and gone home to weep , but something , I know not what , held me there as it were rooted to the ground .
Parsing [sent. 6182 len. 8]: At length the end was drawing near .
Parsing [sent. 6183 len. 46]: He opened his mouth and spake to his mother and the disciple who stood by her , but truly I know not what he said , for as his eyes turned from them , they looked upon me , and my heart died within me .
Parsing [sent. 6184 len. 44]: He said nought , but his eyes had that in them that would have slain me with sorrow , had not death , although I knew it not , already shrunk from my presence , daring no more come nigh such a malefactor .
Parsing [sent. 6185 len. 44]: -- Oh Death , how gladly would I build thee a temple , set thee in a lofty place , and worship thee with the sacrifice of vultures on a fire of dead men 's bones , wouldst thou but hear my cry !
Parsing [sent. 6186 len. 9]: -- But I rave again in my folly !
Parsing [sent. 6187 len. 4]: God forgive me .
Parsing [sent. 6188 len. 15]: All the days of my appointed time will I wait until my change come .
Parsing [sent. 6189 len. 26]: -- With that look -- a well of everlasting tears in my throbbing brain -- my feet were unrooted , and I fled . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6190 len. 13]: Here the reader paused again , and turned over many leaves . ''
Parsing [sent. 6191 len. 92]: ` And ever as I passed at night through the lands , when I came to a cross by the wayside , thereon would I climb , and , winding my arms about its arms and my feet about its stem , would there hang in the darkness or the moon , in rain or hail , in wind or snow or frost , until my sinews gave way , and my body dropped , and I knew no more until I found myself lying at its foot in the morning .
Parsing [sent. 6192 len. 21]: For , ever in such case , I lay without sense until again the sun shone upon me . '' '
Parsing [sent. 6193 len. 51]: ... And if ever the memory of that look passed from me , then , straightway I began to long for death , and so longed until the memory and the power of the look came again , and with the sorrow in my soul came the patience to live .
Parsing [sent. 6194 len. 73]: And truly , although I speak of forgetting and remembering , such motions of my spirit in me were not as those of another man ; in me they are not measured by the scale of men 's lives ; they are not of years , but of centuries ; for the seconds of my life are ticked by a clock whose pendulum swings through an arc of motionless stars . '' '
Parsing [sent. 6195 len. 9]: ... Once I had a vision of Death .
Parsing [sent. 6196 len. 63]: Methinks it must have been a precursive vapour of the madness that afterwards infolded me , for I know well that there is not one called Death , that he is but a word needful to the weakness of human thought and the poverty of human speech ; that he is a no-being , and but a change from that which is .
Parsing [sent. 6197 len. 11]: -- I had a vision of Death , I say .
Parsing [sent. 6198 len. 61]: And it was on this wise : '' ' I was walking over a wide plain of sand , like Egypt , so that ever and anon I looked around me to see if nowhere , from the base of the horizon , the pyramids cut their triangle out of the blue night of heaven ; but I saw none .
Parsing [sent. 6199 len. 20]: The stars came down and sparkled on the dry sands , and all was waste , and wide desolation .
Parsing [sent. 6200 len. 34]: The air also was still as the air of a walled-up tomb , where there are but dry bones , and not even the wind of an evil vapour that rises from decay .
Parsing [sent. 6201 len. 23]: And through the dead air came ever the low moaning of a distant sea , towards which my feet did bear me .
Parsing [sent. 6202 len. 20]: I had been journeying thus for years , and in their lapse it had grown but a little louder .
Parsing [sent. 6203 len. 11]: -- Suddenly I was aware that I was not alone .
Parsing [sent. 6204 len. 14]: A dim figure strode beside me , vague , but certain of presence .
Parsing [sent. 6205 len. 24]: And I feared him not , seeing that which men fear the most was itself that which by me was the most desired .
Parsing [sent. 6206 len. 10]: So I stood and turned and would have spoken .
Parsing [sent. 6207 len. 16]: But the shade that seemed not a shadow , went on and regarded me not .
Parsing [sent. 6208 len. 15]: Then I also turned again towards the moaning of the sea and went on .
Parsing [sent. 6209 len. 3]: And lo !
Parsing [sent. 6210 len. 24]: the shade which had gone before until it seemed but as a vapour among the stars , was again by my side walking .
Parsing [sent. 6211 len. 56]: And I said , and stood not , but walked on : Thou shade that art not a shadow , seeing there shineth no sun or moon , and the stars are many , and the one slayeth the shadow of the other , what art thou , and wherefore goest thou by my side ?
Parsing [sent. 6212 len. 22]: Think not to make me afraid , for I fear nothing in the universe but that which I love the best .
Parsing [sent. 6213 len. 11]: -- I spake of the eyes of the Lord Jesus .
Parsing [sent. 6214 len. 48]: -- Then the shade that seemed no shadow answered me and spake and said : Little knowest thou what I am , seeing the very thing thou sayest I am not , that I am , and nought else , and there is no other but me .
Parsing [sent. 6215 len. 80]: I am Shadow , the shadow , the only shadow -- none such as those from which the light hideth in terror , yet like them , for life hideth from me and turneth away , yet if life were not , neither were I , for I am nothing ; and yet again , as soon as anything is , there am I , and needed no maker , but came of myself , for I am Death .
Parsing [sent. 6216 len. 3]: -- Ha !
Parsing [sent. 6217 len. 2]: Death !
Parsing [sent. 6218 len. 37]: I cried , and would have cast myself before him with outstretched arms of worshipful entreaty ; but lo , there was a shadow upon the belt of Orion , and no shadow by my side !
Parsing [sent. 6219 len. 13]: and I sighed , and walked on towards the ever moaning sea .
Parsing [sent. 6220 len. 9]: Then again the shadow was by my side .
Parsing [sent. 6221 len. 26]: And again I spake and said : Thou thing of flitting and return , I despise thee , for thou wilt not abide the conflict .
Parsing [sent. 6222 len. 21]: And I would have cast myself upon him and wrestled with him there , for defeat and not for victory .
Parsing [sent. 6223 len. 9]: But I could not lay hold upon him .
Parsing [sent. 6224 len. 16]: Thou art a powerless nothing , I cried ; I will not even defy thee .
Parsing [sent. 6225 len. 15]: -- Thou wouldst provoke me , said the shadow ; but it availeth not .
Parsing [sent. 6226 len. 6]: I can not be provoked .
Parsing [sent. 6227 len. 40]: Truly , I am but a shadow , yet know I my own worth , for I am the Shadow of the Almighty , and where he is , there am I -- Thou art nothing , I said .
Parsing [sent. 6228 len. 10]: -- Nay , nay , I am not Nothing .
Parsing [sent. 6229 len. 14]: Thou , nor any man -- God only knoweth what that word meaneth .
Parsing [sent. 6230 len. 52]: I am but the shadow of Nothing , and when THOU sayest NOTHING , thou meanest only me ; but what God meaneth when he sayeth NOTHING -- the nothing without him , that nothing which is no shadow but the very substance of Unbeing -- no created soul can know .
Parsing [sent. 6231 len. 7]: -- Then art thou not Death ?
Parsing [sent. 6232 len. 3]: I asked .
Parsing [sent. 6233 len. 21]: -- I am what thou thinkest of when thou sayest Death , he answered , but I am not Death .
Parsing [sent. 6234 len. 5]: -- Alas , then !
Parsing [sent. 6235 len. 33]: why comest thou to me in the desert places , for I did think thou wast Death indeed , and couldst take me unto thee so that I should be no more .
Parsing [sent. 6236 len. 30]: -- That is what death can not do for thee , said the shadow ; none but he that created thee can cause that thou shouldst be no more .
Parsing [sent. 6237 len. 10]: Thou art until he will that thou be not .
Parsing [sent. 6238 len. 24]: I have heard it said amongst the wise that , hard as it is to create , it is harder still to uncreate .
Parsing [sent. 6239 len. 6]: Truly I can not tell .
Parsing [sent. 6240 len. 11]: But wouldst thou be uncreated by the hand of Death ?
Parsing [sent. 6241 len. 11]: Wouldst thou have thy no-being the gift of a shadow ?
Parsing [sent. 6242 len. 35]: -- Then I thought of the eyes of the Lord Jesus , and the look he cast upon me , and I said , No : I would not be carried away of Death .
Parsing [sent. 6243 len. 14]: I would be fulfilled of Life , and stand before God for ever .
Parsing [sent. 6244 len. 18]: Then once again the belt of Orion grew dim , and I saw the shadow no more .
Parsing [sent. 6245 len. 28]: And yet did I long for Death , for I thought he might bring me to those eyes , and the pardon that lay in them . ''
Parsing [sent. 6246 len. 73]: ` But again , as the years went on , and each brought less hope than that before it , I forgot the look the Lord had cast upon me , and in the weariness of the life that was mortal and yet would not cease , in the longing after the natural end of that which against nature endured , I began to long even for the end of being itself .
Parsing [sent. 6247 len. 34]: And in a city of the Germans , I found certain men of my own nation who said unto me : Fear not , Ahasuerus ; there is no life beyond the grave .
Parsing [sent. 6248 len. 12]: Live on until thy end come , and cease thy complaints .
Parsing [sent. 6249 len. 24]: Who is there among us who would not gladly take upon him thy judgment , and live until he was weary of living ?
Parsing [sent. 6250 len. 11]: -- Yea , but to live after thou art weary ?
Parsing [sent. 6251 len. 3]: I said .
Parsing [sent. 6252 len. 45]: But they heeded me not , answering me and saying : Search thou the Scriptures , even the Book of the Law , and see if thou find there one leaf of this gourd of a faith that hath sprung up in a night .
Parsing [sent. 6253 len. 20]: Verily , this immortality is but a flash in the brain of men that would rise above their fate .
Parsing [sent. 6254 len. 18]: Sayeth Moses , or sayeth Job , or sayeth David or Daniel a word of the matter ?
Parsing [sent. 6255 len. 12]: And I listened unto them , and became of their mind .
Parsing [sent. 6256 len. 47]: But therewithal the longing after death returned with tenfold force and I rose up and girt my garment about me , and went forth once more to search for him whom I now took for the porter of the gate of eternal silence and unfelt repose .
Parsing [sent. 6257 len. 39]: And I said unto myself as I walked : What in the old days was sweeter when I was weary with my labour at making of shoes , than to find myself dropping into the death of sleep !
Parsing [sent. 6258 len. 28]: how much sweeter then must it not be to sink into the sleepiest of sleeps , the father-sleep , the mother-bosomed death of nothingness and unawaking rest !
Parsing [sent. 6259 len. 35]: Then shall all this endless whir of the wheels of thought and desire be over ; then welcome the night whose darkness doth not seethe , and which no morning shall ever stir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6260 len. 44]: ` And wherever armies were drawing nigh , each to the other , and the day of battle was near , thither I flew in hot haste , that I might be first upon the field , and ready to welcome hottest peril .
Parsing [sent. 6261 len. 26]: I fought not , for I would not slay those that counted it not the good thing to be slain , as I counted it .
Parsing [sent. 6262 len. 33]: But had the armies been of men that loved death like me , how had I raged among them then , even as the angel Azrael to give them their sore-desired rest !
Parsing [sent. 6263 len. 31]: for I loved and hated not my kind , and would diligently have mown them down out of the stinging air of life into the soft balm of the sepulchre .
Parsing [sent. 6264 len. 23]: But what they sought not , and I therefore would not give , that searched I after the more eagerly for myself .
Parsing [sent. 6265 len. 34]: And my sight grew so keen that , when yet no bigger than a mote in the sunbeam , I could always descry the vulture-scout , hanging aloft over the field of destiny .
Parsing [sent. 6266 len. 21]: Then would I hasten on and on , until a swoop would have brought him straight on my head . ''
Parsing [sent. 6267 len. 33]: ` And with that a troop of horsemen , horses and men mad with living fear , came with a level rush towards the spot where I sat , faint with woe .
Parsing [sent. 6268 len. 26]: And I sprang up , and bounded to meet them , throwing my arms aloft and shouting , as one who would turn a herd .
Parsing [sent. 6269 len. 29]: And like a wave of the rising tide before a swift wind , a wave that sweeps on and breaks not , they came hard-buffeting over my head .
Parsing [sent. 6270 len. 2]: Ah !
Parsing [sent. 6271 len. 6]: that was a torrent indeed !
Parsing [sent. 6272 len. 21]: -- a thunderous succession of solid billows , alive , hurled along by the hurricane-fear in the heart of them !
Parsing [sent. 6273 len. 22]: For one moment only I felt and knew what I lay beneath , and then for a time there was nothing .
Parsing [sent. 6274 len. 37]: -- I woke in silence , and thought I was dying , that I had all but passed across the invisible line between , and in a moment there would be for evermore nothing and nothing .
Parsing [sent. 6275 len. 10]: Then followed again an empty space as it seemed .
Parsing [sent. 6276 len. 17]: And now I am dead and gone , I said , and shall wander no more .
Parsing [sent. 6277 len. 19]: And with that came the agony of hell , for , lo , still _ I _ THOUGHT !
Parsing [sent. 6278 len. 8]: And I said to myself , Alas !
Parsing [sent. 6279 len. 3]: O God !
Parsing [sent. 6280 len. 62]: for , notwithstanding I no more see or hear or taste or smell or touch , and my body hath dropped from me , still am I Ahasuerus , the Wanderer , and must go on and on and on , blind and deaf , through the unutterable wastes that know not the senses of man -- nevermore to find rest !
Parsing [sent. 6281 len. 2]: Alas !
Parsing [sent. 6282 len. 24]: death is not death , seeing he slayeth but the leathern bottle , and spilleth not the wine of life upon the earth .
Parsing [sent. 6283 len. 2]: Alas !
Parsing [sent. 6284 len. 2]: alas !
Parsing [sent. 6285 len. 6]: for I can not die !
Parsing [sent. 6286 len. 21]: And with that a finger twitched , and I shouted aloud for joy : I was yet in the body !
Parsing [sent. 6287 len. 31]: And I sprang to my feet jubilant , and , lame and bruised and broken-armed , tottered away after Death , who yet might hold the secret of eternal repose .
Parsing [sent. 6288 len. 17]: I was alive , but yet there was hope , for Death was yet before me !
Parsing [sent. 6289 len. 29]: I was alive , but I had not died , and who could tell but I might yet find the lovely night that hath neither clouds nor stars !
Parsing [sent. 6290 len. 16]: I had not passed into the land of the dead and found myself yet living !
Parsing [sent. 6291 len. 17]: The wise men of my nation in the city of the Almains might yet be wise !
Parsing [sent. 6292 len. 14]: And for an hour I rejoiced , and was glad greatly . ' ''
Parsing [sent. 6293 len. 3]: CHAPTER XII .
Parsing [sent. 6294 len. 4]: THE WANDERING JEW .
Parsing [sent. 6295 len. 10]: `` It was midnight , and sultry as hell .
Parsing [sent. 6296 len. 8]: All day not a breath had stirred .
Parsing [sent. 6297 len. 18]: The country through which I passed was level as the sea that had once flowed above it .
Parsing [sent. 6298 len. 29]: My heart had almost ceased to beat , and I was weary as the man who is too weary to sleep outright , and labours in his dreams .
Parsing [sent. 6299 len. 7]: I slumbered and yet walked on .
Parsing [sent. 6300 len. 20]: My blood flowed scarce faster than the sluggish water in the many canals I crossed on my weary way .
Parsing [sent. 6301 len. 15]: And ever I thought to meet the shadow that was and was not death .
Parsing [sent. 6302 len. 6]: But this was no dream .
Parsing [sent. 6303 len. 24]: Just on the stroke of midnight , I came to the gate of a large city , and the watchers let me pass .
Parsing [sent. 6304 len. 55]: Through many an ancient and lofty street I wandered , like a ghost in a dream , knowing no one , and caring not for myself , and at length reached an open space where stood a great church , the cross upon whose spire seemed bejewelled with the stars upon which it dwelt .
Parsing [sent. 6305 len. 11]: And in my soul I said , O Lord Jesus !
Parsing [sent. 6306 len. 20]: and went up to the base of the tower , and found the door thereof open to my hand .
Parsing [sent. 6307 len. 17]: Then with my staff I ascended the winding stairs , until I reached the open sky .
Parsing [sent. 6308 len. 16]: And the stairs went still winding , on and on , up towards the stars .
Parsing [sent. 6309 len. 26]: And with my staff I ascended , and arose into the sky , until I stood at the foot of the cross of stone . ''
Parsing [sent. 6310 len. 4]: ` Ay me !
Parsing [sent. 6311 len. 23]: how the centuries without haste , without rest , had glided along since I stood by the cross of dishonour and pain !
Parsing [sent. 6312 len. 36]: And God had not grown weary of his life yet , but I had grown so weary in my very bones that weariness was my element , and I had ceased almost to note it .
Parsing [sent. 6313 len. 20]: And now , high-uplifted in honour and worship over every populous city , stood the cross among the stars !
Parsing [sent. 6314 len. 43]: I scrambled up the pinnacles , and up on the carven stem of the cross , for my sinews were as steel , and my muscles had dried and hardened until they were as those of the tiger or the great serpent .
Parsing [sent. 6315 len. 53]: So I climbed , and lifted up myself until I reached the great arms of the cross , and over them I flung my arms , as was my wont , and entwined the stem with my legs , and there hung , three hundred feet above the roofs of the houses .
Parsing [sent. 6316 len. 23]: And as I hung the moon rose and cast the shadow of me Ahasuerus upon the cross , up against the Pleiades .
Parsing [sent. 6317 len. 35]: And as if dull Nature were offended thereat , nor understood the offering of my poor sacrifice , the clouds began to gather , like the vultures -- no one could have told whence .
Parsing [sent. 6318 len. 27]: From all sides around they rose , and the moon was blotted out , and they gathered and rose until they met right over the cross .
Parsing [sent. 6319 len. 53]: And when they closed , then the lightning brake forth , and the thunder with it , and it flashed and thundered above and around and beneath me , so that I could not tell which voice belonged to which arrow , for all were mingled in one great confusion and uproar .
Parsing [sent. 6320 len. 85]: And the people in the houses below heard the sound of the thunder , and they looked from their windows , and they saw the storm raving and flashing about the spire , which stood the heart of the agony , and they saw something hang there , even upon its cross , in the form of a man , and they came from their houses , and the whole space beneath was filled with people , who stood gazing up at the marvel .
Parsing [sent. 6321 len. 3]: A MIRACLE !
Parsing [sent. 6322 len. 3]: A MIRACLE !
Parsing [sent. 6323 len. 27]: they cried ; and truly it was no miracle -- it was only me Ahasuerus , the wanderer taking thought concerning his crime against the crucified .
Parsing [sent. 6324 len. 49]: Then came a great light all about me , such light for shining as I had never before beheld , and indeed I saw it not all with my eyes , but the greater part with my soul , which surely is the light of the eyes themselves .
Parsing [sent. 6325 len. 43]: And I said to myself , Doubtless the Lord is at hand , and he cometh to me as late to the blessed Saul of Tarsus , who was NOT the chief of sinners , but I -- Ahasuerus , the accursed .
Parsing [sent. 6326 len. 78]: And the thunder burst like the bursting of a world in the furnace of the sun ; and whether it was that the lightning struck me , or that I dropped , as was my custom , outwearied from the cross , I know not , but thereafter I lay at its foot among the pinnacles , and when the people looked again , the miracle was over , and they returned to their houses and slept .
Parsing [sent. 6327 len. 57]: And the next day , when I sought the comfort of the bath , I found upon my side the figure of a cross , and the form of a man hanging thereupon as I had hung , depainted in a dark colour as of lead plain upon the flesh of my side over my heart .
Parsing [sent. 6328 len. 6]: Here was a miracle indeed !
Parsing [sent. 6329 len. 14]: but verily I knew not whether therefrom to gather comfort or despair . ''
Parsing [sent. 6330 len. 29]: ` And it was night as I went into a village among the mountains , through the desert places of which I had all that day been wandering .
Parsing [sent. 6331 len. 12]: And never before had my condition seemed to me so hopeless .
Parsing [sent. 6332 len. 66]: There was not one left upon the earth who had ever seen me knowing me , and although there went a tale of such a man as I , yet faith had so far vanished from the earth that for a thing to be marvellous , however just , was sufficient reason wherefore no man , to be counted wise , should believe the same .
Parsing [sent. 6333 len. 16]: For the last fifty years I had found not one that would receive my testimony .
Parsing [sent. 6334 len. 88]: For when I told them the truth concerning myself , saying as I now say , and knowing the thing for true -- that I was Ahasuerus whom the Word had banished from his home in the regions governed of Death , shutting against him the door of the tomb that he should not go in , every man said I was mad , and would hold with me no manner of communication , more than if I had been possessed with a legion of swine-loving demons .
Parsing [sent. 6335 len. 17]: Therefore was I cold at heart , and lonely to the very root of my being .
Parsing [sent. 6336 len. 17]: And thus it was with me that midnight as I entered the village among the mountains .
Parsing [sent. 6337 len. 20]: -- Now all therein slept , so even that not a dog barked at the sound of my footsteps .
Parsing [sent. 6338 len. 65]: But suddenly , and my soul yet quivers with dismay at the remembrance , a yell of horror tore its way from the throat of every sleeper at once , and shot into every cranny of the many-folded mountains , that my soul knocked shaking against the sides of my body , and I also shrieked aloud with the keen terror of the cry .
Parsing [sent. 6339 len. 25]: For surely there was no sleeper there , man , woman , or child , who yelled not aloud in an agony of fear .
Parsing [sent. 6340 len. 45]: And I knew that it could only be because of the unseen presence in their street of the outcast , the homeless , the loveless , the wanderer for ever , who had refused a stone to his maker whereon to rest his cross .
Parsing [sent. 6341 len. 12]: Truly I know not whence else could have come that cry .
Parsing [sent. 6342 len. 29]: And I looked to see that all the inhabitants of the village should rush out upon me , and go for to slay the unslayable in their agony .
Parsing [sent. 6343 len. 14]: But the cry passed , and after the cry came again the stillness .
Parsing [sent. 6344 len. 47]: And for very dread lest yet another such cry should enter my ears , and turn my heart to a jelly , I did hasten my steps to leave the dwellings of the children of the world , and pass out upon the pathless hills again .
Parsing [sent. 6345 len. 28]: But as I turned and would have departed , the door of a house opened over against where I stood ; and as it opened , lo !

Parsing [sent. 6347 len. 50]: And the wind blew upon her , and by the light of the moon I saw that her hands and her feet were rough and brown , as of one that knew labour and hardship , but yet her body was dainty and fair , and moulded in loveliness .
Parsing [sent. 6348 len. 65]: Her hair blew around her like a rain cloud , so that it almost blinded her , and truly she had much ado to clear it from her face , as a half-drowned man would clear from his face the waters whence he hath been lifted ; and like two stars of light from amidst the cloud gazed forth the eyes of the girl .
Parsing [sent. 6349 len. 27]: And she looked upon me with the courage of a child , and she said unto me , Stranger , knowest thou wherefore was that cry ?

Parsing [sent. 6352 len. 27]: -- What seemed it unto thee like , she asked , for truly I slept , and know only the terror thereof and not the sound ?
Parsing [sent. 6353 len. 24]: And I said , It seemed unto me that every soul in the village cried out at once in some dream of horror .
Parsing [sent. 6354 len. 29]: -- I cried not out , she said ; for I slept and dreamed , and my dream was such that I know verily I cried not out .
Parsing [sent. 6355 len. 9]: And the maiden was lovely in her innocence .
Parsing [sent. 6356 len. 28]: And I said : And was thy dream such , maiden , that thou wouldst not refuse but wouldst tell it to an old man like me ?
Parsing [sent. 6357 len. 54]: And with that the wind came down from the mountain like a torrent of wolves , and it laid hold upon me and swept me from the village , and I fled before it , and could not stay my steps until I got me into the covert of a hollow rock . ''
Parsing [sent. 6358 len. 12]: ` And scarce had I turned in thither when , lo !

Parsing [sent. 6369 len. 4]: For , lo !

Parsing [sent. 6384 len. 12]: And a great love arose in my heart to the maiden .

Parsing [sent. 6386 len. 7]: And I loved the maiden greatly .
Parsing [sent. 6387 len. 48]: And although my age was then marvellous being over and above a thousand and seven hundred years , yet found she my person neither pitiful nor uncomely , for I was still in body even such as when the Lord Jesus spake the word of my doom .

Parsing [sent. 6391 len. 43]: And although I knew every city upon it , and every highway and navigable sea , yet did all become to me fresh and new because of the joy which the damsel had in beholding its kingdoms and the glories thereof . ''
Parsing [sent. 6392 len. 96]: ` And it came to pass that my heart grew proud within me , and I said to myself that I was all-superior to other men , for Death could not touch me ; that I was a marvel upon the face of the world ; and in this yet more above all men that had ever lived , that at such an age as mine I could yet gain the love , yea , the absolute devotion , of such an one as my wife , who never wearied of my company and conversation .
Parsing [sent. 6393 len. 37]: So I took to me even the free grace of love as my merit unto pride , and laid it not to the great gift of God and the tenderness of the heart of my beloved .
Parsing [sent. 6394 len. 39]: Like Satan in Heaven I was uplifted in the strength and worthiness and honour of my demon-self , and my pride went not forth in thanks , for I gloried not in my God , but in Ahasuerus .

Parsing [sent. 6400 len. 9]: And my heart cried out in an agony .

Parsing [sent. 6411 len. 72]: -- Now , in the last year of my long sojourn , life had again , because of the woman that loved me , become precious unto me , and more than once had I laughed as I caught myself starting back from some danger in a crowded street , for the thing was new to me , so utterly had the care of my life fallen into disuse with me .
Parsing [sent. 6412 len. 66]: But now again in my misery I thought no more of danger , but went stalking and sliding down the sindery slope of the huge fire-cup , and out upon the lake of molten earth -- molten as when first it shot from the womb of the sun , of whose ardour , through all the millions of years , it had not yet cooled .
Parsing [sent. 6413 len. 33]: And as once St. Peter on the stormy water to find the Lord of Life , so walked I on the still lake of fire , caring neither for life nor death .
Parsing [sent. 6414 len. 44]: For my heart was withered to the roots by the thought of the decay of her whom I had loved ; for would not then her very presence every hour be causing me to forget the beauty that had once made me glad ?
Parsing [sent. 6415 len. 57]: -- I had walked some ten furlongs , and passed the middle of the lake , when suddenly I bethought me that she would marvel whither I had gone , and set out to seek me , and something might befall her , and I should lose my rose ere its leaves had begun to drop .
Parsing [sent. 6416 len. 22]: And I turned and strode again in haste across the floor of black heat , broken and seamed with red light .
Parsing [sent. 6417 len. 3]: And lo !

Parsing [sent. 6419 len. 42]: And the black ice broke at her foot , and the fire shone up on her face , and it was lovely as an angel of God , and the glow of her love outshone the glow of the nether fire .
Parsing [sent. 6420 len. 39]: And I called not to stay her foot , for I judged that the sooner she was with me , the sooner would she be in safety , for I knew how to walk thereon better than she .
Parsing [sent. 6421 len. 102]: And my heart sang a song within me in praise of the love of woman , but I thought only of the love of my woman to me , whom the fires of hell could not hold back from him who was worthy of her love ; and my heart sent the song up to my lips ; but , as the first word arose , sure itself a red bubble from the pit of glowing hell , the black crust burst up between us , and a great hillock of seething , slow-spouting , slow-falling , mad red fire arose .

Parsing [sent. 6427 len. 3]: O Decay !

Parsing [sent. 6431 len. 17]: ` And what I had then said in despair , I said yet again in thankfulness .
Parsing [sent. 6432 len. 3]: O Age !
Parsing [sent. 6433 len. 3]: O Decay !

Parsing [sent. 6440 len. 3]: CHAPTER XIII .
Parsing [sent. 6441 len. 2]: REMARKS .
Parsing [sent. 6442 len. 13]: Polwarth closed the manuscript , and for a time no one spoke .

Parsing [sent. 6444 len. 29]: `` I must confess to you , '' returned Polwarth , `` that I have chosen some of the more striking passages -- only some of them however .

Parsing [sent. 6446 len. 13]: `` Could you trust me with the manuscript , Mr. Polwarth ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6447 len. 4]: said the curate .
Parsing [sent. 6448 len. 12]: `` Willingly , '' said Polwarth , handing it to him .
Parsing [sent. 6449 len. 11]: `` And I may carry it home with me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6450 len. 4]: `` Certainly . ''
Parsing [sent. 6451 len. 10]: `` I shall take right good care of it .
Parsing [sent. 6452 len. 11]: Are there any further memorials of struggle with unbelief ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6453 len. 24]: `` Yes , there are some ; for mood and not conviction must , in such a mind , often rule the hour .
Parsing [sent. 6454 len. 25]: Sometimes he can believe ; sometimes he can not : he is a great man indeed who can always rise above his own moods !
Parsing [sent. 6455 len. 22]: There is one passage I specially remember in which after his own fashion he treats of the existence of a God .
Parsing [sent. 6456 len. 14]: You will know the one I mean when you come to it . ''
Parsing [sent. 6457 len. 8]: `` It is indeed a treasure ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6458 len. 14]: said the curate , taking the book and regarding it with prizing eyes .
Parsing [sent. 6459 len. 11]: In his heart he was thinking of Leopold and Helen .
Parsing [sent. 6460 len. 20]: And while he thus regarded the book , he was himself regarded of the gray luminous eyes of Rachel .
Parsing [sent. 6461 len. 80]: What shone from those eyes may have been her delight at hearing him so speak of the book , for the hand that wrote it was that of her father ; but there was a lingering in her gaze , not unmixed with questioning , and a certain indescribable liquidity in its light , reminding one of the stars as seen through a clear air from which the dew settles thick , that might have made a mother anxious .
Parsing [sent. 6462 len. 22]: Alas for many a woman whose outward form is ungainly -- she has a full round heart under the twisted ribs !
Parsing [sent. 6463 len. 7]: Why then should I say alas ?
Parsing [sent. 6464 len. 11]: Were it better that the heart were like the shape ?
Parsing [sent. 6465 len. 13]: or are such as Rachel forgotten before the God of the sparrows ?
Parsing [sent. 6466 len. 121]: No , surely ; but he who most distinctly believes that from before the face of God every sorrow shall vanish , that they that sow in tears shall reap in joy , that death is but a mist that for a season swathes the spirit , and that , ever as the self-seeking vanishes from love , it groweth more full of delight -- even he who with all his heart believes this , may be mournful over the aching of another heart while yet it lasts ; and he who looks for his own death as his resurrection , may yet be sorrowful at every pale sunset that reminds him of the departure of the beloved before him .
Parsing [sent. 6467 len. 44]: The curate rose and took his departure , but the light of the gaze that had rested upon him lingered yet on the countenance of Rachel , and a sad half-smile hung over the motions of the baby-like fingers that knitted so busily .

Parsing [sent. 6470 len. 19]: If there was a hearing ear open to that little house , oh surely those two were blessed !
Parsing [sent. 6471 len. 29]: If not , then kind death was yet for a certainty drawing nigh -- only , what if in deep hell there should be yet a deeper hell ?
Parsing [sent. 6472 len. 26]: And until slow Death arrive , what loving heart can bear the load that stupid Chance or still more stupid Fate has heaped upon it ?
Parsing [sent. 6473 len. 38]: Yet had I rather be crushed beneath the weight of mine , and die with my friends in the moaning of eternal farewells , than live like George Bascombe to carry lightly his little bag of content .
Parsing [sent. 6474 len. 38]: A cursed confusion indeed is the universe , if it be no creation , but the helpless unhelpable thing such men would have us believe it -- the hotbed mother of the children of an iron Necessity .
Parsing [sent. 6475 len. 22]: Can any damnation be worse than this damning into an existence from which there is no refuge but a doubtful death ?
Parsing [sent. 6476 len. 11]: Drew overtook Wingfold , and they walked together into Glaston .
Parsing [sent. 6477 len. 7]: `` Was n't that splendid ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6478 len. 4]: said the draper .

Parsing [sent. 6480 len. 4]: returned the curate .
Parsing [sent. 6481 len. 20]: `` Even through the play of a mad-man 's imagination , the spirit of a sound mind may speak .
